summary: Google Flu Trends was developed to estimate US influenza-like illness rates from internet searches. but ILI does not necessarily correlate with actual influenza virus infections. most of the outlier observations occurred during the 2003–04 influenza season that was characterized by early and intense influenza activity. Google.org developed a model to estimate US influenza-like illness rates. the model was fit to CDC sentinel provider surveillance data for ILI from 2003 to 2007. it was prospectively validated using the same surveillance system during the 2007–08 influenza season. CDC Virus Surveillance consists of about 140 laboratories across the united states that report the weekly total specimens tested and laboratory tests positive for influenza virus. CDC Virus Surveillance is used in CDC statistical models in the estimation of influenza-associated morbidity and mortality [11], [12], [13], [14], [15], [16]. Pearson's correlation coefficients with 95% confidence intervals (95% CI) were then computed from these comparisons. additional correlation coefficients with 95% CI were then calculated from surveillance comparisons by influenza season, US Census Region, and influenza season categorized by US Census Region. correlation coefficients from the sensitivity analysis were compared to the same statistic from the primary analysis. results Our analyses used 166 weeks of data from the 2003–04 through the 2007–08 influenza seasons. data included five influenza seasons from 2003–04 through the 2007–08 influenza season. 2CDC Influenza-like Illness Surveillance involves a network of health care providers who record the weekly proportion of patients seen with ILI. 3CDC Influenza Virologic Surveillance consists of about 140 laboratories located throughout the united states that report the weekly total specimens tested and laboratory tests positive for influenza virus. there are 166 total observations in each panel. Influential observations were defined by DFBETA statistic greater than the absolute value of 2 divided by the square root of the total number of observations. the correlation coefficient describing the association between CDC surveillance ranged from 0.67 (95% CI 0.43, 0.82) during the 2003–04 influenza season to 0.94 (95% CI 0.89, 0.97) during the 2004–05 influenza season. the mean correlation coefficient for these comparisons was 0.79 (SD 0.13). CDC ILI Surveillance had a stronger increase from 0.80 to 0.89 with a one-week lag and 0.92 with a two-week lag. the mean CDC ILI Surveillance correlation with CDC Virus Surveillance decreased from 0.78 (SD 0.04) at baseline to 0.76 (SD 0.08) with a one-week lag. US Census Region3 Dataset Google Flu Trends CDC ILI CDC Virologic New England Google Flu Trends 1.00 -- -- CDC Virologic 0.86 (0.74, 0.93) 0.88 (0.77, 0.94) 1.00 Middle Atlantic Google Flu Trends 1.00 -- -- CDC Virologic 0.84 (0.70, 0.92) 0.91 (0.82, 0.96) 1.00 -- -- CDC CDC Virologic 0.88 (0.84, 0.94) 0.77 (0.58, 0.88) 1.00. 9 (5.4%) of the 166 total observations were found to be influential outliers. 7 of the 9 influential observations occurred from November through December 2003. the calculated correlation coefficient after exclusion of these observations was 0.82 (95%CI: 0.76, 0.87), a 14% increase from the primary analysis. 8 of the 14 observations were from November through December 2003. a prior analysis compared Google Flu Trends data to US Census Region ILI data. google flu Trends statistical model was created and validated using rates of ILI. this is a nonspecific syndrome that is not necessarily caused by influenza virus infection, but used for decades as an indicator of the burden of outpatient influenza illness. independent, prospective validation or improvements upon the model are not possible. a convenience sample of specimens sent to participating laboratories may change over time or through the course of an influenza epidemic. CDC surveillance is intensified from calendar week 40 through calendar week 20 of the subsequent year, we restricted our correlation analyses to this time period.
